article.title: Evidence of Spaceflight-Induced Adverse Effects on Photoreceptors and Retinal Function in the Mouse Eye
article.abstract: The goal of the present study was to characterize acute oxidative damage in ocular structure and retinal function after exposure to spaceflight, and to evaluate the efficacy of an antioxidant in reducing spaceflight-induced changes in the retina.

sections.introduction: Neuro-ophthalmic abnormalities have been identified in astronauts. These complex physiological and pathological changes are collectively defined as spaceflight-associated neuro-ocular syndrome (SANS) [1].
sections.methods: Ten-week-old C57BL/6 male mice were launched in December 2021, at the Kennedy Space Center (KSC) on the rodent research-18 (RR-18) mission for 35 days aboard the ISS.
sections.results: Mice were weighed before launch and shortly before being euthanized after landing. Prior to taking off, the body weights were similar among all groups.
sections.discussion: Observed changes following spaceflight include increased oxidative damage and increased apoptosis in the mouse retinal nuclear layer and photoreceptors.

article.insights_summary: Spaceflight conditions induce oxidative stress in the retina, which may lead to photoreceptor cell damage and retinal function impairment. The study found significant increases in retinal oxidative stress and apoptotic cell death after spaceflight.
article.acknowledgments: Sungshin Choi contributed significantly to the success of our study and we greatly appreciate her support.
